_link.title: I can identify which noble gas an ion has the same electron configuration as

toLevel2.question: When sodium (2, 8, 1) loses one electron to form Na⁺, which noble gas does it have the same electron configuration as?

options.explanation: Na⁺ has 10 electrons arranged as 2, 8, which matches neon, not argon.
Na⁺ has 10 electrons (2, 8); helium only has 2 electrons.
Krypton has 36 electrons; Na⁺ has only 10, matching neon.

toLevel2.question: When chlorine (2, 8, 7) gains one electron to form Cl⁻, which noble gas does it have the same electron configuration as?

options.explanation: Cl⁻ has 18 electrons (2, 8, 8), which matches argon, not neon.
Helium has 2 electrons; Cl⁻ has 18 electrons matching argon.
Krypton has 36 electrons; Cl⁻ has 18 matching argon.

toLevel2.question: Lithium (2, 1) loses one electron to form Li⁺. Which noble gas has the same electron configuration?

options.explanation: Li⁺ has 2 electrons, matching helium's 2 electrons, not neon's 10.
Argon has 18 electrons; Li⁺ has only 2, matching helium.
Lithium readily forms Li⁺ by losing its 1 valence electron.

toLevel2.question: Oxide (O²⁻) has the electron configuration 2, 8. Which noble gas is this the same as?

options.explanation: Argon has 18 electrons (2, 8, 8); O²⁻ has 10 electrons (2, 8), matching neon.
Helium has 2 electrons; O²⁻ has 10 electrons, matching neon.
Xenon has 54 electrons; O²⁻ has 10 electrons, matching neon.

toLevel2.question: Why do atoms form ions with noble gas electron configurations?

options.text: Because noble gas configurations have full outer shells, which are very stable
Because noble gases are the lightest elements
options.explanation: Noble gases are not the lightest; atoms form these configurations because full outer shells are stable.

options.text: Because noble gases have no electrons
options.explanation: Noble gases do have electrons; their full outer shells make them stable.

options.text: Because all atoms want to become noble gases
options.explanation: Atoms don't become noble gases; they achieve the same electron arrangement for stability.

toLevel2.template: Na⁺ has the same electron configuration as {{blank:1}} because it has lost {{blank:2}} electron(s) to achieve a full outer shell.
Cl⁻ has 18 electrons arranged as 2, 8, 8, giving it the same configuration as {{blank:1}}. It gained {{blank:2}} electron(s) to achieve this.
Ions form noble gas configurations because full outer shells are very {{blank:1}}. This is called achieving a {{blank:2}} configuration.

toLevel2.statement: Mg²⁺ has the same electron configuration as neon (2, 8).
toLevel2.explanation: Magnesium (2, 8, 2) loses 2 electrons to form Mg²⁺ (2, 8), which matches neon.

toLevel2.statement: F⁻ has the same electron configuration as argon.
toLevel2.explanation: F⁻ has 10 electrons (2, 8), matching neon, not argon which has 18 electrons (2, 8, 8).

toLevel3.question: Aluminium (2, 8, 3) forms Al³⁺. Which noble gas does Al³⁺ have the same electron configuration as?

options.explanation: Al³⁺ has 10 electrons (2, 8) after losing 3, matching neon, not argon.
Al³⁺ has 10 electrons (2, 8), matching neon with 10 electrons.
Krypton has 36 electrons; Al³⁺ has 10, matching neon.

toLevel3.question: Potassium (2, 8, 8, 1) forms K⁺. Which noble gas configuration does it achieve?

options.explanation: K⁺ has 18 electrons (2, 8, 8), matching argon, not neon.
Krypton has 36 electrons; K⁺ has 18 matching argon.
K⁺ has 18 electrons arranged as 2, 8, 8, matching argon.

toLevel3.question: Sulfide (S²⁻) is formed when sulfur (2, 8, 6) gains 2 electrons. Which noble gas does S²⁻ match?

options.explanation: S²⁻ has 18 electrons (2, 8, 8), matching argon, not neon.
Krypton has 36 electrons; S²⁻ has 18, matching argon.
Helium has 2 electrons; S²⁻ has 18, matching argon.

toLevel3.question: Which of these ions does NOT have the same electron configuration as neon?

options.explanation: Na⁺ has 10 electrons (2, 8) matching neon.
F⁻ has 10 electrons (2, 8) matching neon.
O²⁻ has 10 electrons (2, 8) matching neon.

toLevel3.question: Na⁺, Mg²⁺, and Al³⁺ all have the electron configuration 2, 8. What do they all have in common?

options.text: They are all isoelectronic with neon, having 10 electrons each
They all have the same number of protons
options.explanation: Na⁺ has 11, Mg²⁺ has 12, and Al³⁺ has 13 protons; only their electron count (10) is the same.
All three are positive ions (cations) because they have lost electrons.

options.text: They all gained electrons to reach 10
options.explanation: All three lost electrons to reach 10; metals lose electrons to form positive ions.

toLevel3.question: Calcium (2, 8, 8, 2) forms Ca²⁺. Which noble gas does Ca²⁺ have the same configuration as?

options.explanation: Ca²⁺ has 18 electrons (2, 8, 8), matching argon, not neon.
Krypton has 36 electrons; Ca²⁺ has 18, matching argon.
Ca²⁺ has lost 2 electrons; it no longer has the same configuration as calcium.

toLevel3.template: Al³⁺ has lost {{blank:1}} electrons from aluminium (2, 8, 3) to achieve the same configuration as {{blank:2}}.
Na⁺, Mg²⁺, and Al³⁺ are {{blank:1}} because they all have {{blank:2}} electrons, the same as neon.
Potassium forms K⁺ by losing its one {{blank:1}} electron, achieving the electron configuration of {{blank:2}}.

toLevel3.statement: Both K⁺ and Cl⁻ have the same electron configuration as argon.
toLevel3.explanation: K⁺ (19 - 1 = 18 electrons) and Cl⁻ (17 + 1 = 18 electrons) both have 18 electrons arranged as 2, 8, 8, matching argon.

toLevel4.question: Nitrogen (2, 5) forms N³⁻ by gaining 3 electrons. Which noble gas does N³⁻ have the same electron configuration as?

options.explanation: N³⁻ has 10 electrons (2, 8), matching neon, not argon.
N³⁻ has 10 electrons, matching neon's 10, not helium's 2.
Nitrogen can gain 3 electrons to form the nitride ion N³⁻ with configuration 2, 8.

toLevel4.question: The following ions are all isoelectronic with argon: K⁺, Ca²⁺, Cl⁻, S²⁻. Arrange them in order of increasing ionic radius.

options.text: Ca²⁺ < K⁺ < Cl⁻ < S²⁻ (more protons = smaller for same electron count)
S²⁻ < Cl⁻ < K⁺ < Ca²⁺ (higher charge = larger)
options.explanation: More protons pulling the same 18 electrons makes the ion smaller; Ca²⁺ has the most protons and is smallest.

options.text: K⁺ < Ca²⁺ < S²⁻ < Cl⁻ (metals smaller than non-metals)
options.explanation: The order depends on proton count: more protons = smaller ion for isoelectronic species.

options.text: All four are the same size because they have the same number of electrons
options.explanation: Same electron count but different nuclear charges means different sizes.

toLevel4.question: Beryllium (2, 2) forms Be²⁺. Which noble gas is it isoelectronic with, and why is Be²⁺ much smaller than helium?

options.text: Helium (2 electrons); Be²⁺ is smaller because 4 protons pull 2 electrons much closer than helium's 2 protons

options.explanation: Be²⁺ has 2 electrons, matching helium (2), not neon (10).

options.text: Helium; they are the same size because they have the same electrons
options.explanation: Be²⁺ has 4 protons vs helium's 2, pulling the 2 electrons closer and making Be²⁺ much smaller.

options.text: No noble gas; beryllium ions don't match any noble gas
options.explanation: Be²⁺ has 2 electrons, matching helium's electron configuration.

toLevel4.question: A student says: 'Na⁺ is the same as neon because they both have 10 electrons, so they must have the same properties.' Evaluate this claim.

options.text: Incorrect; although they are isoelectronic, Na⁺ has 11 protons vs neon's 10, giving Na⁺ a positive charge and different properties (it is attracted to negative ions)
Correct; same electrons means same properties
options.explanation: Different nuclear charges mean different properties; Na⁺ is a charged ion that forms compounds.

options.text: Incorrect; Na⁺ has more electrons than neon
options.explanation: Na⁺ and neon both have exactly 10 electrons; the difference is in proton count.

options.text: Correct; Na⁺ and neon are identical particles
options.explanation: Na⁺ has 11 protons and a +1 charge; neon has 10 protons and is neutral. They are different particles.

toLevel4.question: Which noble gas will the bromide ion (Br⁻) be isoelectronic with? Bromine has atomic number 35.

options.text: Krypton (36 electrons), because Br⁻ gains 1 electron to have 36

options.explanation: Br⁻ has 36 electrons (35 + 1), matching krypton, not argon.
Br⁻ has 36 electrons, matching krypton (36), not xenon (54).
Br⁻ has 36 electrons, far more than neon's 10.

toLevel4.question: Phosphorus (atomic number 15) forms P³⁻. Determine which noble gas P³⁻ is isoelectronic with.

options.text: Argon (18 electrons), because P³⁻ has 15 + 3 = 18 electrons

options.explanation: P³⁻ has 18 electrons (15 + 3), matching argon, not neon.
P³⁻ has 18 electrons, matching argon, not krypton.
P³⁻ has 18 electrons, matching argon.

toLevel4.question: In sodium chloride (NaCl), Na⁺ is isoelectronic with neon and Cl⁻ is isoelectronic with argon. Why do these ions attract each other despite having stable electron configurations?

options.text: Because Na⁺ has a positive charge and Cl⁻ has a negative charge; opposite charges attract via electrostatic forces
Because they want to share electrons with each other
options.explanation: Ionic bonding is due to electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions, not electron sharing.

options.text: Because they both have unstable configurations and need more electrons
options.explanation: Both have stable noble gas configurations; they attract because of their opposite charges.

options.text: Because neon and argon attract each other naturally
options.explanation: Na⁺ and Cl⁻ are ions with charges, not noble gas atoms; their attraction is electrostatic.

toLevel4.template: Isoelectronic ions have the same number of {{blank:1}} but different numbers of {{blank:2}}, so they have different sizes.
Br⁻ is isoelectronic with {{blank:1}} because it has {{blank:2}} electrons after gaining one.
Among isoelectronic ions, the one with the most {{blank:1}} is the smallest because the electrons are pulled {{blank:2}} to the nucleus.

toLevel5.question: Na⁺, Mg²⁺, Al³⁺, F⁻, O²⁻, and N³⁻ are all isoelectronic with neon. Arrange the positive ions from smallest to largest ionic radius and explain the trend.

options.text: Al³⁺ < Mg²⁺ < Na⁺; more protons pulling 10 electrons means a smaller radius
Na⁺ < Mg²⁺ < Al³⁺; higher charge means larger radius
options.explanation: Higher positive charge means more protons pulling electrons closer, giving a smaller radius.

options.text: All three are the same size because they all have 10 electrons
options.explanation: Different nuclear charges (11, 12, 13 protons) give different ionic radii despite the same electron count.
Ionic radius depends on nuclear charge, not name; more protons = smaller for isoelectronic species.

toLevel5.question: A student asks: 'Why can't carbon form C⁴⁻ or C⁴⁺ to achieve a noble gas configuration?' What is the best explanation?

options.text: Gaining or losing 4 electrons requires too much energy; carbon instead achieves stability by sharing 4 electrons through covalent bonding
Carbon has no noble gas configuration it could achieve
options.explanation: C⁴⁻ would match neon and C⁴⁺ would match helium; the issue is the energy required, not the configurations.

options.text: Carbon does form C⁴⁻ in all compounds
options.explanation: C⁴⁻ is not observed in practice because gaining 4 electrons is too energetically costly.

options.text: Only metals can form ions with noble gas configurations
options.explanation: Non-metals like F, O, Cl, and S regularly form ions with noble gas configurations.

toLevel5.question: Compare the series: O²⁻, F⁻, Ne, Na⁺, Mg²⁺. All have 10 electrons. How does ionic/atomic radius change across this isoelectronic series?

options.text: Radius decreases from O²⁻ to Mg²⁺ because the nuclear charge increases from 8 to 12 protons while electron count stays at 10
Radius increases from O²⁻ to Mg²⁺ because more protons push electrons outward
options.explanation: More protons attract electrons inward, decreasing radius, not increasing it.

options.text: All five have the same radius because they have the same number of electrons
options.explanation: Nuclear charges range from 8 to 12, creating significant size differences.

options.text: Only the ions have measurable radii; neon does not
options.explanation: Neon has a measurable atomic radius; all five can be compared.

toLevel5.question: Transition metals like iron can form Fe²⁺ and Fe³⁺. Neither of these has a noble gas configuration. Why can transition metals form stable ions without noble gas configurations?

options.text: Because partially filled d-orbitals can provide stability through other electronic effects; the noble gas rule mainly applies to main group elements
Because transition metals don't form real ions
options.explanation: Transition metals regularly form ions; Fe²⁺ and Fe³⁺ are extremely common.

options.text: Because Fe²⁺ and Fe³⁺ actually do have noble gas configurations
options.explanation: Fe²⁺ (24 electrons) and Fe³⁺ (23 electrons) do not match any noble gas.

options.text: Because transition metals always lose all their electrons
options.explanation: Transition metals lose some electrons, not all; stability comes from d-orbital effects.

toLevel5.question: A student says: 'Chlorine gains 1 electron because it needs to match argon, and sodium loses 1 electron because it needs to match neon. So the noble gas configuration causes the ion formation.' Evaluate this causal reasoning.

options.text: The reasoning confuses correlation with causation; atoms form ions to achieve lower energy (stable full shells), and matching a noble gas is a consequence, not the driving force
The reasoning is perfectly correct; noble gases cause other atoms to form ions
options.explanation: Noble gases don't cause ion formation; the drive is toward lower energy through full electron shells.

options.text: The reasoning is wrong because ions don't match noble gas configurations
options.explanation: The ions do match noble gas configurations; the issue is the causal explanation, not the outcome.

options.text: The reasoning is wrong because noble gases don't exist
options.explanation: Noble gases are real elements; the student's error is in suggesting they cause ion formation.

toLevel5.question: Hydrogen can form H⁻ (hydride) with 2 electrons. Which noble gas is H⁻ isoelectronic with, and why is H⁻ much larger than helium?

options.text: Helium; H⁻ is larger because hydrogen's 1 proton holds 2 electrons much less tightly than helium's 2 protons

options.explanation: H⁻ has only 2 electrons (1 + 1), matching helium, not neon.

options.text: Helium; they are the same size because they have the same electrons
options.explanation: H⁻ has 1 proton vs helium's 2, so it holds the electrons less tightly and is larger.

options.text: No noble gas; hydrogen cannot form negative ions
options.explanation: Hydrogen can form H⁻ (hydride) in compounds like NaH.

toLevel5.question: In an ionic compound like MgO, Mg²⁺ is isoelectronic with neon and O²⁻ is isoelectronic with neon. Despite both having neon's electron configuration, why is O²⁻ much larger than Mg²⁺?

options.text: Because O²⁻ has only 8 protons holding 10 electrons, while Mg²⁺ has 12 protons holding 10 electrons — more protons means a stronger pull and smaller size
Because O²⁻ gained electrons and gaining always makes ions larger while losing always makes them smaller
options.explanation: While the effect is correct, the fundamental reason is the difference in nuclear charge, not just the direction of electron transfer.

options.text: Because oxygen is a gas and magnesium is a solid
options.explanation: Physical state of the element is irrelevant to ionic radius; nuclear charge determines size.

options.text: They are the same size because they both have 10 electrons
options.explanation: Different nuclear charges (8 vs 12 protons) cause significantly different ionic radii.

toLevel5.question: Predict which noble gas configuration the selenide ion (Se²⁻) would achieve. Selenium has atomic number 34.

options.text: Krypton (36 electrons), because Se²⁻ has 34 + 2 = 36 electrons

options.explanation: Se²⁻ has 36 electrons (34 + 2), matching krypton (36), not argon (18).
Se²⁻ has 36 electrons, matching krypton, not xenon.
Bromine is not a noble gas; Se²⁻ has 36 electrons matching krypton.

toLevel5.template: In an isoelectronic series, ionic radius {{blank:1}} as nuclear charge increases because more protons pull the same number of {{blank:2}} closer.
Carbon does not typically form C⁴⁺ or C⁴⁻ because transferring {{blank:1}} electrons requires too much energy; it prefers {{blank:2}} bonding instead.
